com.gitlab.ci.schema.Cache0.1.0

  • Properties

module com.gitlab.ci.schema.Cache

Use cache to specify a list of files and directories to cache between jobs. You can only use paths that are in the local working copy. Learn More",

Module URI:
package://opensource.aoe.com/pkl-pantry/packages/com.gitlab.ci.schema@0.1.0#/Cache.pklcontent_copy

0.25.1 or higher

    output: ModuleOutput (pkl.base)Source

    The output of this module.

    Defaults to all module properties rendered as either Pcf or the format specified on the command line.

  • link
    key: String(matches(Regex(#"^(?!.*\/)^(.*[^.]+.*)$"#)))|KeySpecSource

    Use the cache:key keyword to give each cache a unique identifying key. All jobs that use the same cache key use the same cache, including in different pipelines. Must be used with cache:path, or nothing is cached. Learn More.

  • link
    paths: Listing<String>?Source

    Use the cache:paths keyword to choose which files or directories to cache. Learn More

  • link
    policy: "pull-push"|"pull"|"push"|String(matches(Regex(#"\$\w{1,255}"#)))Source

    Determines the strategy for downloading and updating the cache. Learn More

  • link
    unprotected: Boolean?Source

    Use unprotect: true to set a cache to be shared between protected and unprotected branches.

  • link
    untracked: Boolean?Source

    Use untracked: true to cache all files that are untracked in your Git repository. Learn More

  • link
    `when`: "on_success"|"on_failure"|"always"Source

    Defines when to save the cache, based on the status of the job. Learn More.

  • link
    fallback_keys: Listing<String>(length <= 5)?Source

    List of keys to download cache from if no cache hit occurred for key

  • expand_morelink
    function
    relativePathTo(other: Module): List<String> (pkl.base)Source

    Returns the relative, descendent directory path between this module and other.

    Throws if no such path exists.

    For example, if module mod1 has path /dir1/mod1.pkl, and module mod2 has path /dir1/dir2/dir3/mod2.pkl, then mod1.relativePathTo(mod2) will return List("dir2", "dir3").

    A common use case is to compute the directory path between a template located at the root of a hierarchy (say rootModule.pkl) and the currently evaluated module (accessible via the module keyword):

    import "rootModule.pkl" // self-import
path = rootModule.relativePathTo(module)
